script: AddText" As your shuttle descends down the central shaft of the port, you can't help but note how bleak the entire concourse looks. As soon as you disembark, a cold breeze chills you; it seems the heating systems here are either being underused to cut costs, or that the ambient temperature is so frigid that not even the Sector's best thermoheaters can get rid of the deathly cold. The landing area is only populated by a few freighters loading organics for shipment. A dour-faced Diktat logistics officer, evidently resentful of their duty, lazily processes you before moving on to the other incoming ships, for which there are very few."marketFlavorTextColor

AddText" The shuttle lands in the bottom of a crater blackened from past eruptions of organics. Even in your suit you can still feel the cold as you walk across the frozen surface of Drakon towards a nearby maintainence shaft. Upon getting inside, you can feel the suspicious stares of off-duty workers piercing through you as you make your way to the port marketplace without being detected by the patrolling guards in the organics harvesting facility."marketFlavorTextColor

AddText" The air-conditioned main port concourse is populated by a flurry of peddlers selling tourism-related wares, like souveniors or figurines. Many of the usual traits of a Diktat market are absent here, like the noisome propaganda posters, likely to make the planet more accomodating to tourists hailing from other factions. Upon booting up your TriPad, you are imediately assaulted with advertisements for the many planetside amusement parks and zoos, and it takes almost a minute to clear them out. You follow the signs hung on the ceiling of the port, directing you towards the marketplace."marketFlavorTextColor

AddText" Your shuttle lands in the thick of one of the few primary jungles covering Ravaryea so as to avoid detection. Walking out of the shuttle, you are immediately assaulted by the smell of lush greenery and surprisingly humid and hot air, considering the distance of Ravaryea from its sun. Trudging through the thick jungle, you endure almost an hour of insect bites and noisy animal calls before finally reaching a boardwalk trailing along the villas used as habitation for more affluent tourists. The suspicious and alarmed glares of the inhabitants are quickly quelled by your half-hearted excuse that you were a worker checking up on the 'lights in the jungle', and you follow the boardwalk and wooden signs towards the main port concourse. " marketFlavorTextColor

AddText" After touching down in the large and spacious port concourse, you enter the main hall to be greeted with the main entrance of the Lion's Guard Campus, complete with a large purple banner reading 'Serve the Lion, Enrol Now!' draped over it. All around you are students rushing from place to place, or reading books on benches and tables, or chatting with friends. After being processed by the entrance guards, you are escorted to the right wing of the campus, which is where you're told the military equipment and ships are sold, away from the prying eyes of mischievous Guard students." marketFlavorTextColor

AddText" Your shuttle stops over a maintainence shaft in the bowels of the main concourse, away from the many prying eyes of the Diktat patrols surrounding the upper structure. Walking through the dark shaft, you make it into a maze of corridors, apparently one of the lower levels of the academy. A few students pass by you, but they seem to have more pressing matters on their minds than worrying about your presence. " marketFlavorTextColor
AddText "After finally decoding the astonishingly convoluted maps of the academy, you manage to stumble your way to the right wing and somehow manage to make yourself look like a person who was authorized to come here. While most legal traders refuse to trade to you without express evidence that you were authorized, other less scrupulous or desperate traders are more than willing to sell you wares." marketFlavorTextColor

AddText" Weaving through the jutting irregularities of protruding hab-modules, your shuttle makes its way to the gargantuan port module situated in the centre of the complex. The main port concourse is extremely crowded with everything from tramp freighters to transit shuttles to Dikat-marked combat ships residing in the spaceport. Outside of thick multi-layered glass windows, you can faintly see the starlight glint on bronze colour that signifies the multiple Diktat fleets perpetually standing guard over Ryzan Supercomplex." marketFlavorTextColor
AddText " Curiously, on many surfaces, there are reminders to always follow the map of Ryzan Supercomplex given to all spacers who enter it, with a reference to a helpline operated by the Diktat for anyone 'lost in the depths of the Ryzan Supercomplex'. On promenant bulkheads there lie massive maps of the full station; concerningly, dozens of Missing posters cover the area around these maps, the oldest of which are already yellowing and frayed at the edges." marketFlavorTextColor

AddText" Due to the close proximity of Sindria to Askonia, approaching it on the daylight side is nothing less than suicide; Instead, Sindria operates multiple port concourses, all connected to the surface by heavily-insulated blast doors, and whichever port is on the night side is used. Descending through one such opening, your shuttle enters into a cavernous space where dozens of ships, mostly Diktat warships crowd in the subterranean volume. " marketFlavorTextColor
AddText "Being the capital of the Sindrian Diktat, the propaganda ministry has doubled down on its efforts to indoctrinate anyone who sets foot here; on almost every surface there lies at least one purple-white banner, Andrada holoprojector or holoscreen broadcasting propaganda films. " marketFlavorTextColor

AddText" Instead of the usual peddlers, the port concourse is littered are ceaseless holo-ads for Tri-Tachyon licensed brands, touting everything from fast-food to holovision series and jewelry; as well as many shops selling psychoactive substances usually barred in other markets. Tri-Tachyon officials brief offloading merchants on the latest deals on the commodity markets, while in shady bars loan sharks cut deals with the cash-strapped. Many ships docked here are noticably shinier than normal; likely the freighters of wealthy merchants who made a fortune off drug-running or smuggling heavy arms from Tri-Tachyon markets to whoever pays for them the most. " marketFlavorTextColor
AddText "A Tri-Tachyon franchise official welcomes you and offers to update your PDA with the latest Company rates for the local commodity market." marketFlavorTextColor

AddText" Flying over alpine forests, desolate tundras and the remarkably picturesque villas of rich Tri-Tachyon executives, your shuttle touches down in the main port concourse in Xanadu. As the cheapest producer of psychoactive chemicals in the Sector, Eochu Bres is a hub of activity, with dozens of grizzled freighters loading various questionably legal goods, likely bound to be smuggled to the rest of the Sector. Even from the windows here you can see the distant plumes of factory columns llittering the snowy landscape; you idly wonder if the workers in those factories are really being paid, or if they are slaves to collosal debts to the Corporation. " marketFlavorTextColor

AddText" Approaching the cold derelict of the station, one can clearly make out the gaping hole in its centre; the result of the self-destruct of the station's reactor. Despite this, some back-up reactors seem to still be functional, providing enough power to the station to operate the few docking ports that still lay intact. Anything that wasn't destroyed or bolted down has long been looted; your salvage teams note a few gutted frieighter and shuttle wrecks within the maws of the docking ports. This means, you hope, that nobody will come around here to salvage for a long time. " marketFlavorTextColor
AddText " Despite having been destroyed over a decade ago, many of the intact segments within the station bear heavy rad-scarring from the weapons fire and residual meltdown radiation from the battle that happened so long ago, making them unsuitable for any usage. In spite of this, your salvage crews identify some general storage areas that are battered and rad-free enough to act as makeshift storage spaces. " marketFlavorTextColor

AddText" The independent polity in rule here seems to have taken much inspiration from the Corporation it seceded from; the crest looks suspiciously familiar to the Tri-Tachyon logo, the banners are coloured in a blue colour of only a somewhat different shade from Tachyon blue. Much of the sights here mirror those at any normal Tri-Tachyon market, minus the surprisingly common sights of obviously high workers on their breaks. " marketFlavorTextColor
AddText "A cheerful attendant greets you and shows you a standard catalogue of all the commercially available drugs for sale at Kukayin, for both personal use and for export purposes. " marketFlavorTextColor

AddText" After your shuttle lands at the landing bays present on the surface of the planet, you take a long lift ride down into the main concourse, apparently subterranean. The ride seems to be surprisingly scenic, with the lift opening up to views of the underground pocket seas, kelp farms and fish hatcheries being tended by workers in scuba gear in the azure blue water. After stepping out of the lift, you are greeted with a concourse that looks more like the lobby of a hotel than a real port concourse. " marketFlavorTextColor

id: # Bar dialogue for most Diktat worlds

text:
You decide to settle at a locally famous bar, located firmly in the middle ring of the local hive-city, is jostling with activity; the seats and standing areas brimming with patrons, it takes a while for you to get a seat. In the meantime, you decide to look out the open-top balcony to the majesty of the hive city beyond. Patrol skiffs and the occasional frigate fly through large open spaces, monitoring the endless layers of balconies, pathways and overhangs that extend all the way down to where the lights end, while Diktat holobanners of varying size dot the jutted landscape. 

Regardless, you finally get your seat and sit down, scouring the crowded bar for anyone you might be able to wring a job or offer out of.

Due to your less than legal mode of docking with Sindria, you're forced to make do with a low-end bar near the lower extent of the hive-city; where less scrupulous activities proliferate. Faded, flickering Diktat holobanners mark your entry to the establishment, which acts more like a pirate bar than a Diktat one; rowdy groups of labourers converse, squabble and sometimes fight in the dimmed room, only stopped by bouncers at the doors. Everyone suddenly snaps to good behaviour when the occasional Diktat patrol comes round to inspect the area, while anyone who doesn't is beaten into submission with stun batons and dragged away, never to be seen again.

The bar the Diktat shows you to is practically something out of a Tri-Tachyon port; sleek, gleaming architecture, holoprojectors of Andrada and propaganda posters everywhere. Everything from the drinks to the seating seems to be specifically catered for starship captains to converse with others for opportunities; while the modernity of the bar is in stark contrast to the run down look of the arcology it is situated on, or the entire arcitecture that floats on Volturn in general.

The establishment you visit is an open-air local bar; the raft plates creak and shift below you as you walk amongst the locals, most of whom either stare at you funny or just ignore you. Lights on poles shine over the bar area, while a faded and obviously outdated holoprojector depicts the local news talking on the latest arcology rebellion or the deaths caused by the most recent megafauna attack.

You visit a canteen for labourers deep in the depths of the local train-city; the labourers here sport grim, sullen looks and nasty scars, but otherwise keep mostly to themselves. Other than the buzz of propaganda holoprojectors, the drone of Diktat-sanctioned radio broadcasts and a few muted conversations, the concourse is noticeably silent. You look around for anyone who might have something for you.

The cold and nearly-empty bar, painted in a similar stark white to the "livery" of Lion's Guard ships stands in a similarly drab corridor branching from the main concourse. A deadpan bar worker meets your order with the rocky boredom of a barren world as you find a seat and look around. The few other patrons around seem to predominantly be trade convoy captains checking their cargo manifests; you hold hope that at least someone in this chilly crater of boredom might have something that justifies the visit.

You visit a canteen for labourers deep in the depths of the organics harvesting complex; the near-freezing establishment only holds a few labourers using up what little ration credits they get. Food and beverages are handled by an automated terminal, while the labourers here sport grim, sullen looks and nasty scars peeking out of thick Diktat prison vests, but otherwise keep mostly to themselves. Other than the buzz of propaganda holoprojectors, the drone of Diktat-sanctioned radio broadcasts and a few muted conversations, the concourse is noticeably silent. You look around for anyone who might have something for you.

You are forced to stand at the bar, which has no seating space; it seems to be built for express service, with most patrons arriving, getting their orders on speed dial and leaving in a relative hurry. You look around for anyone staying long enough to offer opportunities for you to reap.

The establishment you decide on is tucked in one of the less-renovated areas of the station; holoads over two decades outdated display their ancient ads along the dark and weathered corridor as you approach its entrance. Inside, the signs of the station's prior abandonment and history still lay apparant; dented and rusting metal and patchwork metal plates populate the bar along with the patrons. Whoever runs this bar seems to have an acute interest in the Askonia system's history; posters of the once-grand Askonian Charter hang on the walls, followed with the tattered, patchy flag of some Independent polity you don't remember knowing about. The drinks also seem to be somewhat remniscent of old Askonian recipies modified from lack of knowledge or to keep up with the times.

The bar at the concourse is decorated lively; triangular flags of all the Sector's major powers sway in the breeze as the patrons, many whom are offworld tourists chatter amongst each other. The menu offers a lively selection of drinks from all over the Sector; from Pheonix Stout and Absynth, to King's Favour and Tears of Ludd, this bar seems to serve practically every legal drink in the Core Worlds. They even have a generous helping of the Sector-famously strong Orbital Bombardment; at a somewhat affordable cost too.

The canteen you visit is practically nothing more than a few coolers and rickety tables sheltered by an overhung tarp, with local workers chatting in what seems to be a local dialect of sorts. The buzz of tropical insect analogues and the grainy drone of Diktat propaganda broadcasts playing from a radio combine with the chatter to form a cacophony of white noise. You look around for anyone who might have something for you.

The local bar serves a surprisingly bland array of drinks and food, not unlike one inside an education campus; the waitress tells you it's to set a good example for the Guard students so they don't try anything funny. The wall tiles are intermittently populated by the familar Diktat propaganda posters as well as posters entincing spacers with children to enrol them to the Andoran Academy. Even if you had children you'd still personally prefer the Galatian Academy.

The bar, in a secluded and relatively shadowy part of the right wing lays host to a myriad of less-than-legal activities; savvy Guard students have somehow managed to access this area and now run an underground trade of everything from coloured pens and Tripad mods to small firearms and vials of recreational drugs. Luckily for you, there are also a surprising amount of adult spacers around who might be able to present you something of interest.

text:
The next section seems to be a zoo-like exhibit, where various animals from various planets(mostly Volturn natives or species from League planets, conspicuously enough) are displayed for tourist's enjoyment. These aren't too interesting for a spacefarer like you, but for Sierra it's a whole other story. Like a child being released in one of those giant Tri-Tachyon confectionary hyperstores, she visits each and every one of the exhibits, marvelling at their inhabitants. After touring the entire area, and causing a disturbance among the other visitors, she returns to your side, recounting all the various animal and plant fun facts she's absorbed from all the exhibits.

"Did you know that Suddene Brine Krill have these really mesmerising coloured fur bristles on their sides that they use for courtship rituals? Or that these Madeiran pseudo-algaes-" She suddenly stops in her tracks. As do you, because before you in the middle of the section is a vast circular room bordered by a glass roof, displaying a large pool of water; floating on its surface seems to be a massive mat of algae-like creatures. Before you can react further, she's already next to the railings, reading out one of the placards by the pool of water.

The spinning Diktat crest and the anthem soon fades into a face you know all too well. The face that taunts from the top of the comms board, yet never actually sees you in person. Not until now.

The Lion himself sits on a posh chair in an opulent purple room, surrounded on both sides by hulking creatures that, you can only assume, are the famed Volturnian Lobster Brutes known to inhabit Sindria. Looking you over with an assessor's eye, you can feel his stare glaring deep into your soul.

"Captain $playerName." He starts. "Your reputation among the officers is...remarkable. You have proven yourself a true ally to the Great Cause and everything that the Sindrian Diktat stands for. After all, that is why you are even able to see me in person."

"I know you must very much want to see me in person." Andrada says, sighing. "However, even you cannot gain that kind of privilege. My enemies are numerous; they lie in every concievable nook and cranny, waiting for a moment of vulnerability to strike me down." He says, pounding his fist on the table in front of him to drive the point home. "The Ministry of Intelligence is not paranoid for no reason, Captain $playerName. This is the most we can spare you to keep my enemies at bay. You have no idea how determined they are to get my head." He gestures to the brutes behind him, "Even these, and all the soldiers the Diktat can field are not enough."

"But none of that concerns you much, right? After all, you are but a fleet commander. So, I have a proposition for you." Says Andrada, moving his wrinkled face closer to the screen.

"My Ministries are efficient at their jobs on a faction-wide scale; indeed, one of the best in the entire Sector. However, they are bureaucratic and slow, and cannot mobilize forces against everything that requires it in sufficient time. And there is the matter of public opinion; it would be...embarrassing if the mighty Diktat had to send a task force to destroy every threat. It would only give the Hegemony another reason to invade us."

"That is where you come in." Andrada points a finger straight at you.

"Your forces are skilled; far more skilled than even the top graduates of the Lion's Academy. I myself don't know how you managed it, but it is of no concern. Here's the deal; I'll share to you my contact details, and you can run errands for me personally. No need to involve the Ministry of Defense or anything like that."

"Of course, there will be rewards for you. This is a mercurial society we live in, and few people would work without the incentive of money. After all, fleet commanders like you are always so fond of lining your pockets with ever more credits, no?" A pause. "But of course, I would know too; after all, I was once one of them too."

"Beyond credits, there are other rewards; with my connections, expect to get bounties and equipment you wouldn't get from any other Diktat officer. And you would promote your standing with the Diktat too."
"So, are you interested?" Andrada finishes. His eyes are on you, awaiting your response patiently.

The salvage teams store a digital copy of it for later reference, before allowing you to sit in the seat and read the conveniently placed report.

"HEG-INT Report Page 1: Recording report for presentation to High Hegemon. Local Task Force 11th Jangala detected comms hail from Jangala Station. Received tip-off from independent whistleblower of potential hostile activity in system [database.getId("hesiod")]. Information presented to higher-ups; Task Force 11th Jangala dispatched to affirm claims of whistleblower."

Identified multiple large structure wrecks and 2 planetary bodies; all non-anomalous save for [planet.getId("tripad_annoying")]. Reporting major malfunction in fleetwide TriPad functionality regarding [planet.getId("tripad_annoying")]; TriPad shows null information about specified planetary body. Requesting confirmation for in-depth investigation by task force from higher-ups."

Reporting visual on unknown large planetary object; identified as likely station-class object. Fleetwide TriPad disruptions like that for [planet.getId("tripad_annoying")] recorded on station-class entity. Unknown station-class object bars structre separate from registered salvage entities outside Core Worlds. Requesting salvage team board unidentified station-class object."

"HEG-INT Report Page 4: Successful breach of station facilities recorded; reporting anomalous pressurized nature of interior facilities, as well as potentially useful equipment that will be salvaged soon. Further exploration authorized and will commence shortly."

"Update: Salvage teams were ambushed by hostile forces; 17 casualties recorded. Joint force of marines and civilian militia successfully repel hostiles; 163 casualties recorded. Upon autopsy, hostiles are discovered to be piloted by [DATA REDACTED]; confiscated for potential research and application. Further potentially useful equipment found and looted. Evidence of command room found; exploration will begin shortly."

"HEG-INT Report Page 5: Command room of station reached. Reporting complete wipeout of station consoles save for one document. Contents displayed below."

The document never makes it even slightly clear, but as your vision slowly strays to the sight of the cracked, bleeding planet below, a small niggling thought tells you that it might be something else entirely.

You close the document, getting up and walking over to the command windows. The giant planetary crater looms below, like a freshly-opened wound.

Perhaps you should have just let the derelict structure lie.

text: The man waits for you to sit and prompts you to order a drink, before talking. "Captain $playerName. You have earned much of a reputation around these parts for your actions." He says in a crisp clear tone; you can only assume this person is some sort of Diktat intelligence agent speaking to you. "So, let's get down to business. As you were approaching the dock here you caused...let's say, quite the local commotion." He turns his TriPad to you, which begins to play a bunch of seemingly disjointed media; from Tri-Tap short clips to FikenTube videos. They all depict your Radiant-class Battleship hovering around the station alongside the rest of your fleet, patiently awaiting your arrival from the bar.
options: DEDiktatRadiant2:"So what's this got to do with me?"

text: The agent makes a quick face of annoyance before snapping back to his calm demeanor. "This hull is of an unknown make that has never been recorded in existing databases before. Not to mention scans seem to indicate a complete lack of human crew on it, unless that's just a scanner malfunction." He leans closer. "But I think we both know that isn't the case."

He makes a small chuckle. "Don't be silly Captain $playerName. That secret isn't very well guarded. You can't hide dozens of beacons floating in hyperspace to guard against an apparently long-dead foe. Most of the major factions know by now." He tilts the TriPad back towards himself, scrolling through it once more. "According to our databases these so called 'Remnant' warships should be untameable automated weapons of war, incapable of being controlled by anyone or anything. Even their former masters have seemingly lost their reins. But here you are, parading their most valuable military asset deep inside human space. I'm no Alpha, but I certainly would not be pleased to be sitting mere kilometres from my enemies and not being allowed to pulverize them into space dust." He looks up from the TriPad display, staring straight at you. "Something about you seems to pacify them in a way nobody else can. Almost as if you're...special."

He smirks. "But that can't be true. The Lion is the most special person in all of the Sector. You're just a spacer with a surprising list of coincidences behind you."

A waiter delivers the drinks you ordered. "Ah! The drinks are finally here." He picks up his own drink, sipping the blueish-grey liquid out of the thin glass. "They call this Lobster's Brew. Supposedly made from the essence of Volturnian Lobsters. Not as popular as Askonian Sunshine but I've always been an enjoyer of the less popular things in life. Anyways, drink up; it might help you better consider the first offer I have for you."

"I have a rather simple proposition for you; I ask you to inform me about whatever processes, technology or tricks you use to keep those machines under control. Deal? I'll offer you 3 Diktat Credit points for it. If you don't get that term, it just means your relation with the Diktat will improve. Deal?"

Of course, you're not going to tell him everything; just enough to make it both sound convincing while giving out no truly useful information. Or you could simply reject his offer; though you don't exactly expect him to take it lightly.
options:

text: The agent whips out a pen draped in the white-purple garb of the Lion's Guard, complete with lion figurehead, and begins writing down notes on his TriPad as you ramble on about the maintainence and regulations of automated ships. Of course, you know very well practically all of this information out of context won't lead to anything fruitful, so his frantic note-taking is all for a sham. "Excellent! The higher-ups will be pleased. Now, on to my other offer..."

The agent narrows his eyes. "That's not going to go down well with the higher-ups." A few taps on his TriPad and your own sends out a little chime, indicating you've lost some relation with the Diktat. "I'm guessing you won't like my next offer very much, but I'll continue anyway."

"I simply request for you to hand over the Radiant-class Drone Battleship currently in your possession. Now I know you're thinking that that's preposterous, and honestly, I somewhat agree. But think about it! The Lion serves the Great Cause, to which everything is worth sacrificing for, and your reward will be generous; I promise you I will see to that. And besides, those AI cores have a LOT of these things running about, if intel from the fleets we've sent in is true. You'll be able to find a replacement in no time!" Something tells you he is vastly underestimating the effort of obtaining a pilotable Radiant-class Battleship. "So, what do you say?" He looks at you expectantly, waiting for an answer.

He sits down quickly. "Sorry, I just got...carried away. I'll make the arrangements and you can transfer command of the ship to us." He is typing frantically on his TriPad. You make the necessary calls to your crew to settle the transferrance of ownership of the Radiant; despite the protests of the local ship core and multiple scientific officers you manage to quell them with a few well-placed words and successfully authorize the relinquence of the Radiant to a waiting Company fleet nearby.

Shortly afterwards, you get a ping from the TriPad, and look at it to realized that you've been granted a horrific sum of cash for your "donation to the safety of Sindrian Fuel". "Did you get it?" The agent asks. You nod, and he gets up. "Well then!" He puts on a cheerful demeanor. "That's all for now; you can go now. I don't have any more business with you. And don't worry about the bill; it's on me." He stands up and briskly walks towards the cashier, handing them the bills before striding off.

text:
The holoprojector displays its content for you to read.

"The Opis-Jovian Union(formerly The Askonian Charter): c+0 to c+181"

"The Opis-Jovian Union was a system-wide polity formed in c+21 by the Askonian Charter and the remnants of the Jovian Fuel Corps stationed on Sindria. At the time, the Askonian Charter was suffering from a lack of spaceborne patrol enforcement to defend themselves from regular pirate raids on convoys, while the Sindria remnants, while posessing a well-established military base, lacked resources for sustaining their population without imports. Signing a mutually beneficial agreement, both agreed to unify into the Opis-Jovian Union."

"Now possessing both self-sustainability and self-defense, the newfound polity, similar to Midgard, christened itself as a neutral beacon of safety for all legal starfarers, attracting a large amount of refugees from other polities across the Sector in the process as civilization decayed to the bounds of the Core Worlds. Even as the major powers of the Hegemony and Persean League rose, and as the chaos of the First AI War raged around it, the Opis-Jovian Union stayed relatively stable for upwards of a century, only seeing minor incursions by Remnant and pirate forces."

"However, all was not well within the Union. A stubborn adherance to archaic democracy rules established in the first days of the Union led to a list of increasingly corrupt and inefficient leaders being elected purely out of necessity. Living conditions across the Union plummeted for most, with the richest spending millions of credits on giant luxury-arcologies on Volturn to spend their days in excessive opulence. Furthermore, the elites seemed to enjoy currying the Hegemony's favour in diplomatic discussions; raising fear that the Askonians may one day live under the rule of the likes of Eventide's snobby nobles, or have many of their rights curtailed due to the Hegemony's eternal martial law. This obviously did not sit well for the common people, with protests and riots becoming more commonplace as the cycles dragged on; the Union tried to keep these issues away from the eyes of other powers, but the assasination of the most recent elected leader became the straw that broke the camel's back."

"Many of the hive-cities on Opis descended into civil war, with entire cities seceding from the Union, albeit temporarily as military forces were sent in to crack down on them. Despite the attempts by the Union to quell the unrest, the system-wide chaos was too widespread to fully quell and the planets of Nortia and Umbra even seceded from the Union, declaring independence themselves."

"This unrest, called the Askonian Crisis, obviously drew the attention of the major faction powers; especially since many of the rebels demanded League membership, claiming their military might would help to protect Askonia from the encroachment of the Hegemony and that only this would solve the massive inequality plagueing the once-great polity. Of course, this did not go down well, and the Hegemony sent in a fleet to dismiss the unrest within Union, despite condemnations from any independent polity well-informed enough to know of the political situation within the Union."

"What happened next is very well documented and goes down in history as one of the most catastrophic events in Sector history."

"Most of the Fikenhild-produced holo-documentaries or Holo-Vision shows about the destruction of Opis tend to simply show the moon suddenly blowing up into a million fragments. However, according to handwitness accounts, this is far from the truth. According to eyewitnesses living on Opis at the time, 'First there was a soft rumbling. Like the feeling when a Hound or shuttle lands nearby you or if the radio is turned on too loud. But slowly over time, it got worse. The soft shaking turned more and more severe, causing all of my mugs to fall off the shelves all the time. Luckily they were made of Tri-Tach polymers and were built to withstand that, heh. People really only started panicking when the fissures started appearing. They used to be these wee little cracks the authorities would just pour dura-cement over and forget about. Yet they got bigger, like the rumbling. Pens, TriPads, chairs, dogs, people started falling in them, and eventually, they stopped coming out. Honestly I'd compare it to Cruor, the way the ground on that sorry rock shifts and groans. But it ain't nothing natural, let me tell you that. Well, after the fissures got really massive everyone just started running. Everyone who could, anyway. The authorities would begin holding mass transports in Starliners and it was horribly crowded in those things, and that accursed Hegemony fleet had to keep inspecting every single one of them anyway because of 'security complaints' or whatever. Anyways, I was lucky enough to spend all my credits off on a guy with a Hound who flew me straight out of the system into League space. In retrospect I was Ludd-blessed to have not been sold on Umbra for a quick buck. Guess there still are some good people in the sector after all...'"

"Only after the fissures rocked the planet, collapsing hive-cities, crushing hundreds of thousands in metres of rock and spewing magma all over what was left, did that explosion the Fikens love to portray happen, reducing the once-capital into a nondescript asteroid belt. That was the end of the Opis-Jovian Union; its capital shattered, its population in shambles, the fleets above it fighting amongst themselves."

"The wake of the Opis incident was catastrophic. Other than the millions already dead, thousands more died as their evacuation ships suffered fatal blows from the infighting occuring across the system, not even counting the thousands of crew that died in said infighting. In the end, the purple wings of the Diktat rose from the ashes of the Opis-Jovian Union, ready to take over ownership of the Askonia system."

"Nortia and Umbra remained independent; Nortia built itself into a heavily armed rebel base known as the Charterists, while Umbra descended into piracy under the rule of the Askonian Revolutionary Council. And I think we all know enough about the Diktat by now."

script: AddBarEvent DEDiktatLucanusBar "Walk over to the grim-faced man" "A grim-faced man sits in a far corner of the bar, downing cheap liquor. He wears clothing vaguely remniscent of a Diktat naval uniform."

text:
The man looks up at you as you approach. "You look like someone who runs a fleet of their own. You know, I used to run a fleet of my own too."

He motions to a seat opposite from him. "If you're looking for errands or jobs to run, I don't have any. But if you're willing to listen to an old man ramble about his life, then you can take a seat."

He sighs, and surprisingly, you hear the faint swoosh of a privacy field projecting around the booth. "A few cycles or so ago, I used to be the commander of a grand fleet. Ever heard of 'The Pride of The Executor'?"

You nod; it's that massive Lion's Guard fleet perpetually standing virgil over Sindria. "Well, grand old Andrada wouldn't like you to know this, but that fleet hasn't been around since the Askonia Crisis, unlike what the posters say. Yeah, there's been a few. And they fall, oh they fall often. Usually simply routed by something, though there was one desertion...they just rotate a new fleet in under the cover of a parade or something like that. Anyone from those former fleets they catch?" He makes a throat-slash gesture on his throat. "I was the commander of one of those fleets once. A naive young man I was back then, sucking up all that propaganda like a bottom feeder. Life was good back then, being showered with praises and Andrada's validation."

"Then one day, I get orders straight from Andrada himself. Man wants us to take out a bogey somewhere on the fringe of the Sector. Said it was a bounty for something exotic. AI or something like that? Never paid too much attention to the history books. I remember laughing it off with the bridge crew in a bar while high as stars. A bounty, usually reserved for the mercurial freelancers, sent up to the likes of the sophisticates of the Lion's Guard? We found it hysterical, but of course, Lion's orders, so we set out anyways. He was really adamant on us keeping our ID-IFFs off too...probably not to stir up political drama or whatever."

"Then one day, I get orders straight from Andrada himself. Man wants us to take out a bogey somewhere on the fringe of the Sector. Said it was a bounty for something exotic. Something about the Legio Infernalis; never cared much for them really. I remember laughing it off with the bridge crew in a bar while high as stars. A bounty, usually reserved for the mercurial freelancers, sent up to the likes of the sophisticates of the Lion's Guard? We found it hysterical, but of course, Lion's orders, so we set out anyways. He was really adamant on us keeping our ID-IFFs off too...probably not to stir up political drama or whatever."

A dark shadow passes across his face. "Couldn't have expected what we found in that system. Thoseï¿½things. We had heard the horror stories of the old automated warfleets, but most of us were too young or foolish to take them to heart. Thought they'd be easy prey, an easy paycheck and an easy promotion."

"Turns out there was easy prey. But it wasn't them."

"They...ripped through our fleet. Ships that had only beforehand seen action on the parade grounds, ripped apart by those ships. They outmaneuvered our lines, outflanked our lineships, peeling us like a Volturnian Lobster at a banquet feast. My compatriots, friends..." He shakes his head slowly. "...the casualties were in the thousands. Our warfleet, once so grand, was practically torn asunder by them. The few that lived in escape pods fled on the few limping warships that survived and the logistics escorts. I was lucky to live myself...none of the other bridge crew made it when the Hand of Andrada was destroyed."

A dark shadow passes across his face. "Couldn't have expected what we found in that system. Thoseï¿½things. The Legio Infernalis were pirates at heart, always using shoddy pirate constructs mainly, with only a few semi-decent ships on their roster. Thought they'd be easy prey, an easy paycheck and an easy promotion."

"Turns out there was easy prey. But it wasn't them."

"It was nothing like what I've every seen for that faction. They...ripped through our fleet. Ships that had only beforehand seen action on the parade grounds, ripped apart by those ships. They outmaneuvered our lines, outflanked our lineships, peeling us like a Volturnian Lobster at a banquet feast. My compatriots, friends..." He shakes his head slowly. "...the casualties were in the thousands. Our warfleet, once so grand, was practically torn asunder by them. The few that lived in escape pods fled on the few limping warships that survived and the logistics escorts. I was lucky to live myself...none of the other bridge crew made it when the Hand of Andrada was destroyed. The worst part was that they actively intercepted the pods, pulling anything they could catch into their holds. I don't want to know what became of those who were captured."

"Took us over a month to limp back to Askonia on our shattered warfleet. And Andradaï¿½he wasn't pleased. It was like all my achievements, all that validation was a show, a ployï¿½as soon as I stopped being useful, he threw me away and replaced me with a more loyal subordinate. And as for the rest of us?"

A slow sigh. "Remember what I said about those who failed Andrada?" You nod. "That's what happened. All of us, consigned to execution. A few of us tried to escape. They never came back. I still remember the day of the execution. Most of the guards treated me like one of Cruor's slaves, or a common criminal, and they even made me watch my comrades get executed."

"Of course, eventually it came up to me. Butï¿½" He drinks from the liquor bottle. "I have no idea what happened that day. Maybe it was just a massive coincidence. Or maybe Ludd does exist, and decided to spare me. But something happened to the facility we were in. Caught snippets from guards, seemed to be a Pather attack...never thought those damned terrorists would somehow help me one day."

"I wasn't going to stick around any longer to find out though. And neither did my fellow crewmen. In the chaos, we got out of that horrible place, right into the dark underbelly of Sindria. We've been here since, those of us who survived; I think it's been 10 cycles, give or take? Some of the others didn't take the experience too well, and are probably drinking themselves to death on bars near the bottoms. Others took on odd jobs, trying to get by. We're still trying to keep our heads down though; there's apparently wanted holoprojectors of us on the upper layers, though nobody cares enough down here."

"Well, that's itï¿½I'm still surprised someone decided to listen after all this while. I only remember telling the tale a few times, and I think this has been the first time in possibly cycles."

"I suppose I should pay the bill. Well, I'll get going now, hopefully we meet again in time." He gets up, taking both of the now-empty cups and bottle to the bartender, paying up, and leaving. You note that he's left a small piece of paper on the table; on closer inspection, it seems to be a keycode for a personal comm-link. Odd.

text:
Specks float on blue-black like stars in space in the light cast out into the crushing depths. It is an almost unsettling wrongness from a familiar image. Motes of something or other flick to and fro.

"Life prevails even here, under unthinkable oppression," the curate says. "Let us be thankful, too, for the ingenuity granted to us by Providence," she taps the pressure hull, which resounds dully. "See? We do not hate all technology."

In the inky darkness of the depths, you swear you see something massive moving. A deep magenta, barely perceptible from the surrounding depths, as well as accompanying groans and creaks from the module. The floor subtly shifts and roils beneath you.

text:
The curate sighs, looking to the viewport. "It isï¿½a thing. A monster, abomination. It was not made by Providence, but ratherï¿½something else entirely. Or should I sayï¿½" Her eyes narrow. "...someone."

"They do not bother us down here, mercifully. At best, a few shakes and rattles. But sometimes I pray for the wellbeing of those in the arcologies on the surface. Those...they bear the brunt of the beasts' attacks. You'll know if you check the planetary holonews."

"Simply put, the plan - and my fellow patriots are in agreement - is to test and provoke the leaders of the Sindrian Diktat's three arms of power. They will either prove their loyalty to the vision of the Supreme Executor, Lion of Sindria, Philip Andrada, or they will show themselves to be corrupt cowards and traitors who must be executed to ensure the purity of the Great Cause."

"First, the navy. While the Grand Star Marshal is nominally in charge, he lies half-conscious in a clinic on Sindria. The Supreme Executor should have replaced him a cycle ago, but," Ram pauses significantly, "has not."

"In his place, Deputy Star Marshal Oxana Hyder commands the Askonia System Defense Armada, while the Star Marshal's original fleet lies stranded like a wallowing beast over Sindria. She is... unimaginative, and I suspect she regrets leaving the Hegemony behind during the Battle of Salus."

"Captain. I shall be forthright out of respect for a fellow officer."

"It is," her lip curls in a sneer, "Intolerable. I have not been given due authority, yet I have responsibility for the System Defense Armada."

"Macario, through Caden, seeks to starve my fleets and make me look incompetent. He wiggles the Star Marshal's former armada like a Volturnian Angler's bait glow at me over Sindria, whilst I am forced to run the temporary System Defense Armada instead. Philip Andrada would never have stood for it, if he was capable. If he wasn't beguiled by flatterers and liars. If he was the Philip Andrada I pledged myself to during the Battle of Salus!"

"Provided the navy did not stand in his way, provided the Supreme Executor was... dead. Then he would be the next in line."

"Could he lead?" She scoffs. "The Lion's Guard is his personal empire, his church, his cult, sucking up resources for a parade-navy. He wastes his time commissioning self-destructive pieces of junk with barely any care for basic warship doctrine, on weapons far too inefficient for anything other than a ordnance parade. We could have made the Sindrian Diktat strong, even great, but Caden had to start a religion. And we had to end up as the guinea pigs of our so-called 'benevolent benefactors', who probably don't see us as anything more than a politically safe way to test their dangerous tech."

She looks away, "Andrada enjoyed the... the worship. He favored Caden, and it blinded him, impaired his judgment. Caden would martyr us all to the idol he's built of Andrada. I doubt even Macario could really control him. I'm sure he thinks he can."
"Then it seems that I owe you a death," Macario says, nodding reasonably. "That I can provide."

She seems surprised at this question. "I respect you, Captain, but surely you must understand that the Diktat is not as stable as it loves to portray itself. Behind the parade-fleets that fly past Askonia and Andor, the holoprojectors depicting a strong nation, lies turmoil, infighting and inefficiency. Likely what Macario has already told you."

She sighs, looking upwards for a brief moment, before her eyes settle on you. "The Diktat was a great nation, once. Under Andrada's rule, it rose to power at a rate other polities could only dream of. But now, under the control of incompetents like Caden and meddlesome worms like Macario, it has begun rotting from the inside out."

Her face contorts in fury. It seems you've struck a nerve.

"Do not speak of that event to me, Captain. You barely know what you're talking about."

Her face contorts in fury, but quickly falls to sorrow.

"The Naval Partitionï¿½one of Andrada's great mistakes, his critics say, where he scrapped half his navy overnight for reasons as frivolous as enforcing autarky. The navy lost many, many perfectly good ships that night." She stares wistfully beyond the comms screen. "And what we got back were cobbled monstrosities of those decomissioned ships, running advanced, experimental technologies in place of reliable systems. Technologies that do little to increase the survivability of the Navy in combat."

"The Diktat's enemies would do well to say that this was a sign that Andrada was a delusional megalomaniac, but I doubt it. The Andrada I pledged my loyalty to would not gut his fleet like that." She says, a dark shroud forming  over her eyes. "It must have been Macario, acting under Caden. That bug, feeding lies to Andrada, undermining his sense of judgement...and causing him to gut our navy like this."

text:
The door flies open in a flash, the thud of a shockwave buffets you back a half-step, ears ringing.

Blurred shadows burst in, targeting lasers flickering, firearms covering you and Ram. Through the settling cloud of dust steps a man in a long black coat over a perfect black uniform, a pistol in his hand.

Ram gapes, hands raised; now, mercifully, at a loss for words.

Somehow, you already know what's going to happen.

You look around for something, anything to block the pistol's bullet, but there's nothing near you that could cushion the impact sufficiently. Nothingï¿½except yourself. So you jump.

The pistol in the man's hand barks once.

Everything goes black.

When you wake, you're blinded with light, a sea of white around you. What is this? The Great Beyond? Have you perhaps unceremoniously passed after your little stunt?

Yet, as you come to, the smell of disinfectants begins to filter in. It's too stark, the fluorescing glow-lights now visible against the ceiling. This is no afterlife. Must be a planet-bound infirmary.

You look down, noting that your torso has been covered with bandages. But you don't get long with yourself, as medical staff rush in from outside, seemingly surprised that you've risen so soon.

"Captain $playerName," One of them starts, "Are you feeling alright? Ah, we didn't expect you to wake up so soonï¿½not in a coupleï¿½days." He seems somewhat uneasy, but perserveres.

You tell them that you're feeling fine, much to the shock of the medical staff. They take some time to process this odd situation, before finally speaking. "Well, if you're feeling fine, then we can schedule your discharge later today. As well as the bill." You nod, and most of them take their leave. One of them adds, "Also, you have a scheduled visitor coming in to see you. He'll be arriving shortly.", before exiting through the doorway.

You're left with more questions than you have answers. Who is this mysterious visitor? You don't remember scheduling any visits, nor would anyone you know be willing or able to come. This was a stranger, with potentially unknown motives.

text:
You reach to the counterside phone to dial up the receptionist for more information, but are interrupted by movement in your peripheral vision. You look back, noting that someone has entered your room. Likely your mystery visitor.

He bears the jet-black suit of the Sindrian Diktat's internal security ministry, over a black coat. The same coat, you realise with a start, that you saw moments before blacking out in that run-down safehouse. And now, under the gleam of the room's glow-lights, you recognise exactly who this man is.

"Captain $playerName," says Dolos Macario, head of the Sindrian Diktat internal security ministry, in-person.

The Spider of Sindria, they call him, who lurks in the Lion's shadow and strings up his enemies, extracts their secrets, and makes them suffer before they are 'disappeared'.

"What an awkward first meeting." He glances at you, smiling like a corpse. "My humblest apologies."

"I suppose you have many questions Captain, and I shall answer them." He continues, still grinning.

"The first of which would likely be to question where Yannick Ram is. A well-placed question." He stares at you. "Why, if I remember correctly, you jumped in front of my pistol for him. Was it an act of revenge? Or perhaps you secretly pitied him? It does not matter now. Allow me to show you what happened of him." His smile widens. He seems to be having fun, dangling this information above you.

The holoscreen in the room flickers on, showing a dead corpse in a detainment cell, blood still pooling from a prominent gunshot wound in the head.

You realise who exactly this is, too late to do anything.

Macario's smile widens. He's having fun feeding you this grim information. "Captain, Captain, Captain. I admire your bravery, to jump in front of a primed weapon like that. It could be...useful. But for all the struggling it does, a fly can never escape a spider's web..." He tuts, as if lecturing a dead Ram at his own foolishness. Or you.

The gunshot was recent; the corpse still leaks fresh blood. He must have arranged for this, for Ram to be executed right before this meeting - just so he could relish in the delight of watching your hope be torn away.
"So, Captain. Shall we speak?"

You begin to rise from the infirmary bed, only for Macario to tsk disapprovingly. "Now now Captain, let's not be so hasty. After allï¿½" He gestures to shadows moving in from the hallway. Marines, you realise, their gun sights trained on you. Macario must have been perceptive enough not to go alone. "...it's rude to make a mess. Besides, we're civilised folk. Best not to stoop to the violence the Resistance and the Charterists love to peddle, hm." He stares deep into your eyes, knowing very well he has the upper hand here.

With no other choice, you sink back into your bed.

"So, Captain. Shall we speak?"
Macario looks at you reasonably, "In that we are agreed."
"Justice?" Macario raises his eyebrows, "How interesting."
"Then it seems that I owe you a death," Macario says, nodding reasonably. "That I can provide."

"Captain Ram was a traitor and has met the end which all traitors deserve," Macario leans back into a nearby recliner, looking thoughtful. 

"I am embarrassed to admit that he was also - in the broad strokes - correct in his assessment of current state of our dear Sindrian Diktat. And his plan is a reasonable one."

"I have decided to enact it, with your cooperation."

Macario smiles thinly.

"The plan is simple enough. In light of the Supreme Executor's upcoming... transition, we must root out treason and corruption at the highest level - by which I mean, of course, those arms of the state which project violent force: the navy, in the person of Oxana Hyder, and the Lion's Guard, in the person of Horacio Caden."

"I, of course, see to the reliability of my own ministry," his eyes flick to indicate the holoprojector showing Ram's corpse.

"Once the means of force are purged of traitors, they shall burn out the rot that has taken root in this Great Project: the so-called Volturnian resistance and the double-blight of Nortia and Umbra in rebellion. Once our power-base in Askonia is consolidated, the Diktat may turn its gaze outward."

You decide to simply shrug at him. The tale of how you acquired these exotic armanents would probably be too confusing anyways.

He takes a few seconds to stare alternatingly at his cargo manifest and the commscreen, before finally speaking. "I suppose these will be helpful...whatever they are...". He does an affirmative nod, making you aware that despite the poorly understood nature of the armaments you've just given up, you've certainly helped their cause out.

Though, somehow, you feel that somewhere...someone else has become a little more disappointed in you.
He raises an eyebrow, before folding his hands backwards. "What do you need to know from me? If you have spoken to Hyder, then you must have already heard everything you want to find out."

A long sigh, and the faint swoosh of the privacy field activating. "It is true. The Pride of The Executor - it was originally the Grand Star Marshal's fleet. The flying jewel of the Supreme Executor himself, it was filled with the best ships that money could buy, the best crew trained from the Academy. It was to be the stalwart claw protecting Askonia's heart from the advance of foreign forces. And when the time came, it would have been a glorious masthead, the javelin to pierce through the feeble resistance of the Degenerates as the might of the Diktat Navy crashes onto them like an unstoppable onslaught of fervor and power!" He waves his clenched fist in the air patriotically, before it falls in a sullen display of renouncement.

"But of course, that is not what you see, is it?" He lets out a bitter laugh. "Now all we do is rot over Sindria. Like everyone else. With the Grand Star Marshal incapacitated, and the Supreme Executor..." He takes a while to choose his words here. "...unavailable, all we can do is hold station over Sindria until a new Grand Star Marshal is elected."

"It is...unfortunate." The tightening in his face suggests that it may be an understatement. But he merely continues to speak. "But without the Supreme Executor, we cannot do anything more. Why, if he was present to see through with Hyder's promotion, she would be able to take the rightful helm of this fleet and...solve our myriad pressing concerns."

"But he is not." He gives you a look of grave significance, before speaking in a considerably lighter, yet sanitised tone. "Anything else?"

And Macario..." His eyes dart quickly to the left and right. "...is slime. Through and through.

"YetÉI have heard of rumors." He elaborates, staring straight at you. "Talk of things happening there. Whatever it is I do not know, but from the way those who know of those rumors carry themselves..."

"...and the way they have a tendency of disappearing, something may be afoot." He adds darkly. "You know of Macario, yes? Perhaps he may know something."
